Wouldn't it be easier to agree with him that he's in a hotel? He has dementia. He's not going to get it. I had a friend who's dad had dementia. His wife died many years ago. He thought she was at the hair dressers and they went along with it. Why fight with the poor guy?

I love my patients with dementia. I always tell new staff the patient's life stories so they can see the person and not the negative behavior... when the behavior does arise. I tell the family.. In the end it's hardest on you... your love one is living in their world... a world where they still contribute to society & they're not sick... it's you (the family) that sees the reality... and the reality is heart breaking.

Hats off to the grandson for making this documentary and showing so much patience  and compassion towards his grandad, lovely family and it highlights the difficult situation carers find themselves in.
What an uplifting story in a world that seems constantly filled with sadness. Angela, it shows what a great job you and Andy are doing for your mum x
My parents both are suffering with vascular dementia it's truly awful xx

I'm so scared of this disease. My nan has it. She was my second mum.. she loved all her grandkids and kids so much but now she remembers no-one. She used to feed me bathe me comb my hair but now she just looks at me like I'm a stranger. 😔😔😢 I hope they find a cure for it.
I felt like his family acted like they were the victim's. You could see it stressed him being told he was I'll. But always reminding him . what a lovely man he was. he just wanted his wife

maybe we shouldn't really pass judgement until we have been in this position ourselves. I look after the elderly with this illness and I see their families so lost and broken and helpless. I think this man was sectioned for his own safety and not that the family were nasty. It turned out to be a happy ending where ️love was found again I thought them to be a lovely caring family towards him

I don't understand this documentary, I found it quite disturbing. The crying and saying 'I feel sorry for you' etc . This is not how families living with dementia would be taught to behave around him. I'm concerned that they had been given no knowledge of what dementia really is and how to behave around someone with it. I lost my father with dementia last year and so I do sympathise with how hard it is to deal with but this is not the right way 😢
Was a v good show! With Alchzeimers you don't got the slow decline as with vascular dementia. Both are horrific and effects the whole family

This really got to me, a real eye opener in how families have to watch their loved ones fade away to this horrid condition. My heart goes out to you all. It was very heartwarming at the end to see them laughing and joking again. Xxx

Family members who are dealing with their loved ones who are suffering from dementia can get help from the Alzheimer Society.  From personal experience the support of the Alzheimer Society was one of the most important parts of the journey.  They gave me the knowledge and confidence to redirect my mom"s attention, avoid daily conflicts and reassure me that taking care of myself also needed to be a priority.  The staff at the Alzheimer Society are always there to listen and help.
My dad died on the 27th May he had Parkinson's and dementia it's a very hard to watch someone you love so much fade away and become a shadow of the amazing man he was.
My had and died with Alzheimer. We took car of him at home until the very last day. God bless the best man ever walked on northern Italy.

A touching example why the people of this country need a first class health and social care system to help and support people and their families through the difficulties of the frailties of life, and ideally support people to live as long as they can with their families. We would be a poorer nation if we could not do that.

As a caregiver of those with dementia, one thing that continually frustrates me is the lack of teaching of the progression of dementia and the ones who are suffering are the loved ones.  I so wish families could get the teaching they need so that they can cope better with their loss and grief.

It's got to be hard to watch a loved one go through this .  My nanny passed away  with this illness,  very sad . Before she passed she would go back to childhood,  and her parents,  and also looking for the son she lost when he was two ... it's truly very sad ....

My grandmother has dementia. It's hard because she is just a shell of her former self. A cruel fate. She was a schoolteacher and very artistic, intelligent woman . 

She is at the stage where she is having a hard time feeding herself unless you keep telling her to eat, she has to wear diapers. She just sits and waits. It's really hard to deal with. We were very close. She was like a second mother to me

I'm a nurse for dementia patients and family members should know, it's okay to say you need a break. Don't feel guilty about taking some time out for yourself. I do see that patients with dementia thrive much better with family and love ones but, the random bouts of confusion or anger and be a bit overwhelming; especially when your busy with your own life. Just reach out for help when you need it.

Thanks for sharing this story.  My dad is near the bottom of his steady decline since his stroke in 2005.  He was always so strong and healthy and into fitness, but now he can barely stand or talk.  He gets confused a lot. I spent the last three nights with him in the hospital after he broke his hip last week, and part of the time he thought I was one of his old high school friends. They just discharged him, and so now it's back to the nursing home.  It's heartbreaking for everyone in our family.

My mum has Alzheimer's and I know my dad found this hard to watch. On his recommendation I watched it too. This programme went a long way in showing just how all members of the family are affected. Heartbreaking decisions, stress and guilt all have to be dealt with while the sufferer disappears into their own world. It's a cruel disease and programmes such as this broaden people's awareness which can only be a good thing.

This film only looked at part of the journey, unfortunately as it is a progressive disease it will only get worse. Some patients are extremely aggressive and violent and being at home isn't always an option. Change of medication, trying to find the triggers for it, and planning care appropriately may help in the short term. It's an ever changing condition, and the film didn't highlight numerous challenges with dementia i.e. wandering, incontinence, poor appetite, dangerous behaviour etc

Don't judge till you've walked in their shoes, the family don't section him, the health authority do. We had to put mum in respite care for dementia 18 month ago, in that month dad was diagnosed with terminal cancer so mam stayed there and I thank god she didn't have to watch him die. She's happy where she is and we visit everyday, she's convinced dad visits too, I think his family (especially his grandson) were lovely

Thank you for sharing your story as so so many silently go through this. We lost my father to dementia last month after a 7 year battle with it. Its beautiful you captured your grandfather while he still has vigor and clarity. Your family will cherish these memories always. Bless you and your family...and especially your grandfather. I'm sorry its such a tough road.

I watched this. Heartbreaking :'( but he seemed to be doing very well at the end of the programme. Dementia is a frustrating, heartbreaking and cruel disease. God love all who go through this whether it be yourself going through it or a family member who has to watch a loved one go through it. :,(

I managed 5 minutes of this and had to switch it off. I really didn't agree with the way his family dealt with him it was hard to watch. That poor man. My dad has  Alzheimer's, he knows it and struggles with it and is frustrated beyond belief. He told me the other day that he 'hates this life' . It was hard to hear. I wish I could take this awful disease away from him
She didn't won't to be bothered been married to long pissed at him he is not in a bad stage of it to be in a insane place shame on her
Disagree with the judgemental comments on here. I thought it was a very brave documentary and the family were very honest and loving but allowed difficult moments to be shown.

Dementia kills more people than breast cancer does. The ratio of researchers working on a cure for dementia to breast cancer is 1-7!!!
My Mum has Lewys body dementia, she hallucinates! It's really sad to watch someone who was your rock in life never smile, whose not happy and her biggest fear is going in to a home. 
It's a vile disease and I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy let alone my Mum.

Bit disappointed with the documentary, only showed the very early stages of the disease things get a lot lot worse. Lost my father-in-law to dementia last year and would not wish it on my worsed enemy.

I thought the family handled this badly. It broke my heart if I'm honest. Having had 3 grandparent suffer from both Alzheimers disease and vascular dementia, I think that sectioning someone is an absolute last resort- not the first thing you do. He was confused and angry and frightened. I realise it was difficult and done out of some misguided notion of doing the right thing but Im really surprised that that was the first thing they did, seeing as he wasnt even that bad. 😢
I thought it was brilliant how it portrayed the impact his dementia had on all his family sometimes I felt his family were cruel n yet they had his best intentions at heart ..fascinating  documentary

I thoroughly liked this post. It clearly shows he didn't have Alzheimer's which is what I think they thought he had. Dementia is a natural aging process with some people. Years ago when my grandmother had it they said it was from hardening of the arteries in the brain. It did become progressively worse but we loved her anyway. Thank you BBC.

I watched this and boy it was bloody awful. I can tell you know I hope by the time I get old and if by bad luck I get dementia as soon as I get the diagnosis I want out and I want out to be legal in my Country. I don't want my family to have to go through this and I sure don't want to be put into Care as the care for the elderly here is disgusting. You wouldn't leave your dog in an old people's home it's that bad.

Is it really so unusual for someone coping with the loss of their vitality    and facing their mortality to feel despondent over loss of his freedon, and call his placement a hotel versus a forced hospitalization? As a coping mechanism, 
it would seem? Often, very depressed and neglected elderly get labeled with dementia, but it can improve with love, support and compassion. So glad for the happy ending, good for Nan.

One nice story but unfortunately most don't go like that, mum fought for 8 years the last 2 she didn't know us, dad being going about 7 years doesn't know us and I wish it was over. Glad they got a more positive story though

Looks like some of the people who commented here has not taken cared of or has lived with someone with dementia. It can take toll on someone no matter how much patience that person has. Just watch, reflect, empathize and research.

My beautiful Mum had dementia, but she was always happy. I only lived next door but one to her, so I looked after her all day, early evening, until my brother got home. I'd put her to bed & be there in the morning for her. 
Please do TRY to keep your family member at home, where they're being constantly stimulated !! 
They didn't leave you as a
baby, please don't walk away now !!! xx

People who r affected by dementia need to b surrounded by family and friends 
 They respond better if attention is provided by loving understanding members of family. 
My opinion. Is that they should not b isolated in a hospital

I can relate to this... my mom has Dementia for the last 3 years ...We are dealing with it on a day to day basis.... I and my twin sister take care of our mom...My dad passed away 16 years ago... Its an uphill task were each person goes through lot of emotional  turmoil and yes there are many days were you just don't know how to deal with it....Yes its all about how much love you really have for your family.....One should always have faith in God ....

You should never ever say anything like I feel really sorry for you etc ...not impressed by any of this at all ... My Mum has Vascular dementia so I can empathise with this family but there's definitely a way of talking to Dementia sufferers and this is not the way :(

For those who chose to say such negative things then all I can say is shame on you. The basic rule is - if you have nothing nice to say then say nothing at all. This brave and honest documentary has made me both laugh and cry. A truly beautiful family who I have shared many wonderful holidays in Cyprus with. Heartfelt love to you all ❤️❤️❤️

My dad is currently in a care home as he was getting too violent and he is better behaved now, he's diabetic, stroke survivor and dementia sufferer. great programme shows the difficulties we face day to day and for people that dont know an eye opener, i have to admit i turned off before the end too sad and close to him, will rewatch it all sometime.

Dominic...your video was brilliant x 
It showed me.....deep love...sadness...frustration ...fear....but much happiness ....whatever way you and your family are "dealing with Grandad's illness ..together...say's a lot about the way you feel about your Grandad...enough to be willing to deal with ..perhap's ..less sensitive feedback.
I personally thank you for sharing your lovely Grandad....and for sharing what is...for me...a fear.
So emotional! What a lovely man, good on his family for still seeing him and geting him out of being sectioned. Some people just ditch family members and let them rot in such places! ❤️❤️

One thing that people don't always know about dementia is that aggression and anger is a part of it. It's not who that person really is. It's just a devastating disease. I wish more research would go into dementia.
Its so heartbreaking watching your loved one go through this..i was bawling watching this as my dad had dementia before he passed away ... Biggest love to your family amd especially your grandad x

I am a gerontology nurse this family is coping they are doing what is right. The constant mental abuse a dementia patient gives is awful for the caregivers. We see caregivers becoming ill themselves .
I wish this family well.

It is tough on home caregivers to properly take care of a disabled person who also suffers from dementia. Good alternatives to home care are scarce and expensive - at least in the United States. The typical nursing home is more of an institution than a home - and depressing for residents and visitors. Many families have to rely on Medicaid to cover the cost of care because it is so expensive. There's got to be a better way.

Anytime someone has a family member with dementia, it is a hard thing to deal with - people all cope in different ways.  My mum had dementia and it was really hard to see and cope with.  My heart still aches, and I miss her so much.

Short term memory loss is quite common in older people.Does that qualify as dementia? Also anger and aggression could also be due to many other reasons. Were they all ruled out before qualifying him as having dementia. He seems like a normal senior citizen to me!

Unfair comments about the family treating him badly. It's a learning curve...and it's as terrible for the family who are trying to work out how they should react and behave. A very emotional time for everyone and such a fear of the future too.

I'm a nurse and deal with patients with Dementia and Alzheimers disease regularly. The love, care and support you and your family offer your grandfather is quite awesome! He is so fortunate to have such a great and caring support system!!

I found the family meant well but failed. Poor Granddad was constantly corrected everytime he was confussed and told he had dementia over and over again. The family wasn't short of a bob or two so could easily of hired good quality carer to take the strain from his wife in the bad periods. But all Granddad needed was to feel wanted and loved not challenged... or treated as a naughty child and isolated. Thank God the Grandma came to her senses and allowed him to come home.
My dad was diagnosed almost four years ago, I can totally relate to this video and what my mother is going through with him at home. I look forward to seeing the rest of your documentary.

There needs to be more support for the carers and loved ones of people with dementia, and also for there to be greater understanding that dementia can cause changes to the brain that alter the individual's moods and personality. Bless you granddad.

My Mom lived with us just as her dementia was starting. We did not understand what she was going through, and neither did she. She was very irritable and always angry, and I in turn very annoyed. It was very hard to watch her be like that. Eventually she became calmer and more accepting, just like the Granddad in this article. I believe a person just needs time and love in order to cope and finally accept this - on both sides.

He's wife was 81 and I expect found the changes so hard to accept after being together for so many years! It takes a long time to understand dementia so the stress of dealing with a loved one when you are old yourself must be a real worry, but she managed in the end and that was a wonderful thing to see 😊
My nana suffered with dementia and it broke my heart when she no longer recognised me. It was after my grandad died that she went downhill, it was all very sad and she never got any better :(
I work in an old people's home and I can truly say dementia and related degenerative brain conditions suck. I mean they really really suck.

When my mam first went into a care home we purposely kept it impersonal as she thought she was in a hotel. We even made sure the suitcase was on the wardrobe at the front to help keep this idea in her mind. It made the transition easier for her. At home she was in a house with a strange old man she didn't know and it was scary for her. There she was happy and thought she was on holiday, dad visited her every day without fail until we lost him. But he went knowing she was happy and well cared for.

Just watched this and it's heartbreaking for all concerned but what an incredible family who dealt with this the best they could. Obviously the children and grandchildren just wanted to protect their parents/grandparents the best they knew how without any guidance or real knowledge x

Dementia is a bloody awful disease. My step dad had it for many years. It was so difficult to watch him fade away. For all of those worrying "but the rescuers could have been taken out as well," that's the point.  These individuals chose to risk their own safety to rescue complete strangers.  That kind of selflessness matters.  Too bad there's not more of this type of sentiment, instead of "well, I got mine, so screw everyone else."

Glad this family was saved but a human chain in surf is an extraordinarily risky rescue. Many years ago off Coast Guard Beach on Cape Cod in heavy surf dozens of people formed a chain to rescue a teenager in a riptide. They were all swept out and the burden on the lifeguards that day was highly dangerous.

NWS Rip Current Safety video is extremely informative about what to do if caught in a rip current and how to spot one in the first place. I'd recommend everyone watch it and inwardly digest before a trip to any beach. Lifeguards or no lifeguards.

I'm impressed with what these folks did (live here along the northwest Gulf Coast).  I do wish folks who aren't strong swimmers would pay attention to signs.  Here in Pensacola we have signs at the beaches telling folks what to do if caught in a rip current - and it isn't "try to swim to shore".  Mother nature doesn't take ignorance lightly.

Swimming parallel to the shore line at the first sign of a rip current is the best way to avoid getting sucked all the way out. Call for help as loud as possible, wave your arm if able, but swim parallel!!! I'm so happy this worked out well but all of these people could have been seriously injured or taken out with the current.
